phrasetype.name: Control Panel Help Text
phrasetype.phrase:
This option allows you to display project information within the forum list on the vBulletin main page.

You may select one or more forums after which to display information about this project, including last activity time and number of issues.

The following caveats apply:
  1. A user must have permission to view the forum this project is supposed to follow.
  2. A user must have permission to view at least one of the selected issue types for this project.
  3. The project's information will be displayed after any child forums for the forum you select.

Not all issue types are applicable for all projects, so you may choose to use only those types that apply for this specific project. Each project may use different types, which enables very deep and powerful permission control.

To make an issue type available to a project, you must select a start status. When users that cannot change the status of an issue submit a new issue, it will start in this state.

To manage issue types and statuses, click here.

If you choose to use the "Display After Forums", this option allows you to override the project name when the project is displayed in the forum list. This is helpful if the project's name does not provide enough context when surrounded by forums.

If you do not enter a value for this option, the project's default name will be used but preceded by the word "Project".

This option allows you to specify which fields cannot be left at the default "Unknown" value when an issue is created or edited. For the fields you select, "Unknown" will still be selected by default, but the issue will not be savable until the value is changed.

Categories allow a simple way of sub-grouping issues within a project based on what the issue relates to. This can be useful if you have several people working on a project and each person has their own specialty.

Categories are definable per project. If you do not define any categories for a project, the option to select a category will not be displayed when submitting an issue. However, a value of "unknown" will still be shown when viewing an issue.

Projects are an organizational unit for a collection of things that need to be completed or analyzed. This can be anything from tracking changes in a piece of software or personal to-do lists to a list of steps to perform a move or build a car.

Issue types let you sub-group tasks/issues in a project into more logical units. A project may have as many custom issue types as you wish. See here for more information on issue types.

A project may also utilize categories for additional sub-grouping. Categories have no functional changes except for grouping issues into logical sub-components, allowing for quicker searching. Categories differ from issue types in that they group based on "where" the issue is accomplished instead of "what" the issue is to accomplish.

Basic version tracking is also provided on a per-project basis. Version tracking is especially useful in a software environment, where the specific revision an issue applies to is very important.

A basic system to track versions is included in the Project Tools. This is especially handy for software projects, where the exact version an issue applies to or is addressed in is important information.

Versions are split into version groups and individual versions. A version can only exist within a version group. This allows users to make searches on entire groups more easily. Using vBulletin's releases as an example, "3.6.x" would be a version group and "3.6.7" would be a version within that group.

Note that the versions you create need to cover two situations: applicable versions and addressed versions. In addition to any versions you have explicitly created, the addressed version will always include an option for "Next Release". This allows you to only create the next version when it's actually needed. When creating the version, you will have the option to denote it as the next version. If you choose to do this, all issues that were listed as being addressed in the next release will be updated to show as being addressed in the version you are just created.

A Note about Version Display Orders
In all other areas of vBulletin and the Project Tools, a lower display order will be displayed before a higher one. This is not the case with version and version group display orders. Higher display orders will be shown first!

This was done because you will generally be adding newer releases over time. With the "lower is first" option, placing the new releases first would require renumbering all of the existing releases.

The issue petition system is a powerful system that allows users to ask for an issue's status to be changed. For example, the fix for a problem may not work for them, so they may request a change to "confirmed" rather than "fixed". This request will then appear on the project overview page until it is handled by someone with the appropriate permissions.

However, there are some cases where you don't want users to have this power when an issue is in a specific status. A common choice is to set this option to "no" for a type's starting status.
Can Create Petitions from this Status?

Tags are a way of defining flexible meta-data about an issue in a searchable way. How they are used is entirely up to you. They could be used to help categorize issues or could be used when certain types of follow ups are needed.

Depending on permissions, tags may be able to be defined on the fly via the front-end.

This allows you to display a small icon representing this issue type next to issues of this type. An icon allows for quicker identification than simple text. Leave this field blank and no icon will be displayed.

You must manually upload this icon to your "Item Status Icon" folder. By default this is images/statusicon.

The included icons for bugs, features, and tasks are 16 pixels by 16 pixels.

Issue types allow you to group issues based on their purpose. For example, you may want to keep feature suggestions separate from bug reports; "features" and "bugs" would become separate issue types.

While different issue types do not cause different fields to be displayed, they do have the following advantages:
  • Specific wordings - all issues have 2 version fields: "applicable" and "addressed". You can choose different, more appropriate wordings for these fields that fit with your types.
  • Custom issue statuses - issue statuses are defined per type.
  • Distinct permissions - a wide range usergroup permissions are definable per project and issue type.

(This topic is also detailed here.)

Reports allow you to save searches for easy access at a later time. Reports are available via the "My Reports" dropdown shown on several Project Tools pages.

A report may either be public (accessible by anyone with search permissions) or private (only accessible to the creator). If guests are allowed to search, a public report may be accessible via RSS.

The Project Tools include an extensive and powerful system to manage access. It is based on the vBulletin permission system. Be sure that you understand the basics first!

Like the usergroup-forum permissions split in vBulletin, the Project Tools include a global permission and project permissions split. If a custom permission set is not defined for a specific group and project, the global set will be used.

Permissions are not only definable per usergroup and per project, but per issue type as well. A group may have access to the bugs in a project but not the feature suggestions, for example.

There are also several permissions that are not definable per project or issue type. Generally, these permissions would not make sense to be defined more than once. These are only editable when you edit the global project permissions for a group.

phrasetype.name: Permissions
phrasetype.phrase: Can Create Public Report <dfn>If you set this to no, but "Can Create Report" to yes, users will still be able to create private reports.</dfn>
Can Create Report <dfn>If you set this to no, users will not be able to create any reports.</dfn>
Can View Project Tools <dfn>If this is set to no, users will not have any access to the Project Tools regardless of other permission settings.</dfn>

phrasetype.name: Scheduled Tasks
phrasetype.phrase: Sends out daily digest notifications for the Project Tools.
Sends out weekly digest notifications for the Project Tools.

phrasetype.name: Email Body Text
phrasetype.phrase:
$notification[username],
$issuenote[username] has just replied to an issue you have subscribed to entitled '$issue[title]' in the $project[title_clean] project of $vboptions[bbtitle].
This issue is located at: $vboptions[bburl]/project.php?do=gotonote&issuenoteid=$issuenote[issuenoteid]
Here is the message that has just been posted:
*************** $pagetext ***************
There may be other replies also, but you will not receive any more notifications until you visit the forum again.
All the best, $vboptions[bbtitle]
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To manage your issue and project subscriptions, click here: $vboptions[bburl]/projectpost.php?do=managesubscriptions

Dear $issue[username],
You are subscribed to the issue "$issue[title]" by $issue[submitusername], there have been $issue[newposts] post(s) to this issue, the last poster was $issue[lastpostusername]. $vboptions[bburl]/project.php?issueid=$issue[issueid]
These following replies were made to the issue: $notebits
All the best, $vboptions[bbtitle]
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To manage your issue and project subscriptions, click here: $vboptions[bburl]/projectpost.php?do=managesubscriptions

Dear $project[username_clean],
You are subscribed to "$project[issuetype_plural]" posted in "$project[title_clean]". There have been $newissues new issues(s) and $updatedissues updated issue(s) since the last digest.
$vboptions[bburl]/project.php?do=issuelist&projectid=$project[projectid]&issuetypeid=$project[issuetypeid]
The following issues are new: $newissuebits
The following issues have been updated with new posts: $updatedissuebits
All the best, $vboptions[bbtitle]
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To manage your issue and project subscriptions, click here: $vboptions[bburl]/projectpost.php?do=managesubscriptions

Dear $assignee_userinfo[username],
You have been assigned to the issue "$issue[title]" by $assigner_userinfo[username].
$vboptions[bburl]/project.php?issueid=$issue[issueid]
Project: $project[title] Issue Type: $issue[issuetype]
All the best, $vboptions[bbtitle]

$reportinfo[rusername] ( mailto:$reportinfo[remail] ) has reported this issue note:
$vboptions[bburl]/project.php?do=gotonote&issuenoteid=$reportinfo[issuenoteid]
This is part of the project: $reportinfo[ptitle] $vboptions[bburl]/project.php?projectid=$reportinfo[projectid]
This is the reason that the user gave: $reportinfo[reason]
$reportinfo[discuss]
This message has been sent to all moderators of this area, or all administrators if there are no moderators.

[url=$vboptions[bburl]/member.php?u=$reportinfo[ruserid]]$reportinfo[rusername][/url] has reported an issue note.
Reason:[quote]$reportinfo[reason][/quote] Issue Note: [url]$vboptions[bburl]/project.php?do=gotonote&issuenoteid=$reportinfo[issuenoteid][/url] Project: [url=$vboptions[bburl]/project.php?projectid=$reportinfo[projectid]]$reportinfo[ptitle][/url] Assigned Moderators: $reportinfo[modlist]
Posted by: [url=$vboptions[bburl]/member.php?u=$reportinfo[puserid]]$reportinfo[pusername][/url]

Each issue type must have at least one status.

phrasetype.name: FAQ Text
phrasetype.phrase: The Project Tools system adds project management capabilities to the $vboptions[bbtitle]. Depending on how the administrator has configured this system, you will likely be using it to report bugs or make suggestions.

The Project Tools attachment system is rather similar to the standard vBulletin attachment system, though the exact file types and sizes that you are allowed to attach will likely differ.

The unique aspect relates to its handling of patch files. A patch file is a specially formatted text document that can instruct a computer on how to make specific changes to another text document without destroying the rest of the content.

In the Project Tools, if you upload a ".patch", ".diff", or ".txt" file in unified diff format, we will automatically display a highlighted version of the patch with the attachment. This allows less technical users to apply your changes, but still allowing you to use a computer program to generate the file.

Remember that only patches in the unified diff format will be highlighted. If you upload any other kind of attachment, it will be processed like any other file.

Posting into the Project Tools should look similar to other areas in vBulletin. However, you generally need to concentrate more on the content. The key to posting a good issue is to make your point clearly and try to answer any possible questions before they come up. Remember to:
  1. Search before posting
  2. Include what you did, what happened, and what you expected
  3. Only include one item per issue

Search before posting

Before posting, it is very important to search the Project Tools. If you've found a problem or have an idea, it's quite possible someone else has too.

Include what you did, what happened, and what you expected

It is very important to layout exactly what you did, in a step-by-step manner if necessary. Try to include all the information that you think would be helpful, but don't be overly verbose.

Now try to explain what happened the best you can. If you received an error message, it is always important to include the full, specific message. The people in charge of managing the project will be able to make use of this. If you're having trouble explaining it, pictures can be better than 1000 words. Use the attachment option whenever reasonable.

Finally, try to explain what you expected to happen. This helps everyone understand what you were thinking and will often lead to improvements.

Remember that it is always better to provide too much information than too little. Think about the type of questions that might come up regarding your issue. If you had a problem with something in your web browser, including information on your browser and operating system would most certainly be needed.

Only include one item per issue

This helps organization. If you explain multiple problems in one issue, then it makes it hard to categorize them. Some might be the correct behavior while others are legitimate issues. It gives everyone a better sense of what's going on and helps encourage more people to handle the issues.

If you make an issue or a reply private, only a limited selection of people will be able to see it. You should use this when discussing things of a sensitive nature, such as security or information covered by an NDA.

Only mark items private when they really must be private.

Reports allow you to save searches for easy access at a later time. When you are subscribed to a report (either by creating it or subscribing to someone else's), you will have access to that report via the "My Reports" dropdown.

To create your own report, make a search with the criteria that you want and click the "Save this search as a report" link.

Base Permissions off of Existing Project
Base Permissions off of Existing Type<dfn>If you select "none", no one will have permission to use this type by default.</dfn>
Can Create Petitions from this Status?

You chose to delete one or more issue types from this project. To complete this process, you should choose a new issue type and status to move all affected issues into.

If do not do this, the issues will remain but become inaccessible until their type is re-enabled for this project. To skip this process and go back to the project list, click here.
If you specify a date here, this milestone will be moved to the "Completed Milestones" list.
Denote as next version?<dfn>If selected, any issues marked as being addressed in the "next version" will become associated with this version.</dfn>
Display After Forums <dfn>This project's information will appear in the forum list after the selected forums.</dfn>
Tip: You can double-click a permission name to quickly grant or revoke that permission for all issue types!
The edit link will be colored this way if custom permissions exist.
Edit Permissions for '{1}' in '{2}'

Issue Type Key<dfn>A-Z, 0-9, and underscore only</dfn>

These permissions will apply to all projects unless you specify a custom set of permissions for a specific project and user group.

You have successfully installed vBulletin Project Tools, version {1}.
Your vBulletin Project Tools has been successfully upgraded from version {1} to {2}.

After upgrading from Project Tools 1.0, it is recommended that you:
  • Enable the "Send Email on Issue Assignment" setting on the projects you want.
  • Set the "Issue Completed" flag on issue statuses as necessary.
  • Check the new project permissions to make sure they are correct for your users.
  • Rebuild issue counters followed by project counters to take advantage of improved tracking of private notes.
Can Make Issues/Notes Private During Creation
Can Edit Private Setting After Creation
Can Manage Issues/Notes <dfn>Allows management of the deleted status and IP address viewing.</dfn>
Can Edit Issue Statuses when Assigned
Can Edit Issue Statuses when Unassigned
Can Edit Issue Tags when Assigned
Can Edit Issue Tags when Unassigned
Rebuilding issue counters will update various fields related to an issue that might become out of date but can be rebuilt.
Rebuilding milestone counters will update various fields related to a milestone that might become out of date but can be rebuilt.
Rebuilding project counters will update various fields related to an project that might become out of date but can be rebuilt. Run this once you know your issue counters are up to date.
Required Fields<dfn>When submitting an issue, the following fields must be populated.</dfn>
Revert to default permissions? <dfn>If you choose this option, the selected permission sets will be deleted and the users in this group will use their global project permissions.</dfn>
Select the start status for the issue types you wish to be available for this project.
Send Email on Issue Assignment <dfn>Choose this option if you want users to receive an email when they are assigned to an issue by another user.</dfn>
Some issue fields, such as project and issue type, are not editable via the front-end. This system allows you edit those fields.
Use this option to specify the target (or deadline) for this milestone.
Title in Forum List <dfn>If you display this project in the forum list, you can use this to override the project's name in the list.</dfn>
This usergroup's access to the Project Tools is globally disabled. The changes you make here will not be applied until that is changed.
Vote Question<dfn>Example: Can you reproduce this bug?</dfn>

phrasetype.name: User Tools (global)
phrasetype.phrase: Find all issues with posts by {1}

phrasetype.name: vBulletin Settings
phrasetype.phrase: Allow users to include BB Code in issues? (Such as [b], [i] etc.)
Allow users to display images via [IMG] codes in issue?

Allow users to include raw HTML code in issues?
(Strongly not recommended.)
Allow users to include smilies in issues?
If you set this to yes, the issue starter will be able to vote on the issue (such as to confirm that they can reproduce the issue).
Allow Issue Starter to Vote on Issue?

The Project Tools allow different file types to be attached than the forum. Enter the file extensions that users will be allowed to attach to issues here.

Put each extension on a separate line.

Making this blank will allow all extensions. To disable attachments in the project tools, set the "Maximum Issue Attachment Size" to 0 or use permissions.
The maximum allowed attachment size, in kilobytes.

When performing a grouped search, how many issues should be displayed in each group on the first page?

A value of 0 will display all issues in a group on the first page.
Set to yes if projects are set to show up as forums.

This is the number of issues to display per page in the issue list.

A value of 0 will display all issues on one page.

This is the number of notes that will be displayed per page in an issue. A note can be a comment/petition or information about changes to the issues details.

A value of 0 will display all notes on one page.

On the Project Tools' overview page (which lists all projects), a timeline section is displayed. This controls the maximum number of timeline entries to display here.

A value of 0 will hide the timeline from this page.

When viewing a project's information, the most recent issues are displayed. This controls the maximum number of issues to display on this page.

A value of 0 will hide the recent issues from this page.

When viewing a project's information, this controls the number of timeline entries that will be displayed.

A value of 0 will hide the timeline from this page.

When viewing the timeline page, this controls the number of entries shown on each page.

A value of 0 will display all entries in the specified time range on one page.

setting.defaultvalue: gif jpe jpeg jpg png xml zip txt patch diff
